discussion.content:
The virtual machine must use EFI firmware.
You can enable a vTPM for virtual machines running on vSphere 6.7 and later (Hardware v. 
14)
https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-vSphere/6.7/com.vmware.vsphere.security.doc/GUID-3D39CBA6-E5B2-43E2-A596-B9A69B094558.html

comments.content:
Virtual machine requirements:

EFI firmware
Hardware version 14

questions.question_text: What are two requirements to implement vTPM in a vSphere environment? (Choose two.)
What is required for host attestation to secure the hypervisor?

choices.C: The VM has an RDM in virtual compatibility mode.
choices.D: 1GbE adapters are in use for the vMotion network.
choices.A: CPU affinity is enabled on the VM.
choices.B: The ESXi hosts use IPv6 addresses.

questions.question_text: Which configuration could prevent an administrator from performing a vSphere vMotion migration?

comments.content:
I believe it's A as well.
I use 1GbE adapters for vMotion in my lab and have never had an issue with migration.
I can reproduce the error described in the link above by trying to migrate a VM that has CPU affinity configured.
That is vsphere 7 and it talks about a corner case not a requirement

The 6.7 documentation also states that using 1Gb adapters could cause vMotion not to work. While in the VMware docs nothing is mentioned about vMotion issues and CPU affinity. The kb linked also mentioned here is for 4.x and 5.x
https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-vSphere/6.7/com.vmware.vsphere.vcenterhost.doc/GUID-0540DF43-9963-4AF9-A4DB-254414DC00DA.html and
https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-vSphere/6.7/com.vmware.vsphere.resmgmt.doc/GUID-199F1ADD-3B9B-490C-8F0C-440B53577B3A.html
I would go for D

questions.question_text: Which action should be taken to ensure vSphere Update Manager (VUM) is available?

choices.C: Enable VUM in the vSphere Client.
choices.B: Consider Windows based vCenter for compatibility.

discussion.content:
A - for secure environment with no internet connection
B - not relevant 
C - VUM is enable by default on vSphere Web Client
D - Install VCSA in order to get VUM feature

So pick whatever you like since question itself is not clear enough for people to choose either A or D. Obvious choice is D, but I don't know how people get C.
by default the plugin will be enabled . https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-vSphere/6.7/com.vmware.vsphere.update_manager.doc/GUID-EF6BEE4C-4583-4A8C-81B9-5B074CA2E272.html

If the VUM plugin is not enabled within the vSphere client, then its not available to use. Yes it is installed with VCSA and yes its enabled by default, but again, if its not turned on, its not there to use
it is itegrated in vcsa. D is ok

questions.question_text:
A vSphere administrator is trying to publish a content library.
How is the Publish this content library externally option made visible in the settings?

choices.D: Choose a library that is not subscribed.
choices.B: Use a library that is not already published.

comments.content: That logic supports Answer D, which says to choose a library that is NOT subscribed.

discussion.content:
Correct answer is D
There is no option to publish a subscribed library.
https://4sysops.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/07/Enable-automatic-synchronization-of-the-content-library.png

https://www.vladan.fr/wp-content/uploads/images/New-content-library.png

Correct is A
You can use the option to download content from the source published library immediately or only when needed to manage your storage space.

Synchronization of a subscribed library that is set with the option to download all the contents of the published library immediately.
https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-vSphere/6.5/com.vmware.vsphere.vm_admin.doc/GUID-254B2CE8-20A8-43F0-90E8-3F6776C2C896.html
